Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2008 06:29PM sharonlouise wrote: hey all--terry. & terry---there's some evidence that ovarian suppression w/Lupron before/during chemo protects ovaries from damage.
Posts.Title: is my chemo too far from surgery?? sharonlouise sharonlouise

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2011 10:03AM sharonlouise wrote: Hi Julie, I was in a similar situation & I opted for chemo. I figured, it was just four months out of my life. I did taxotere & cytoxan, and at the end of the day, it wasn't so bad. I lost my hair, yes, and I was fatigued, definitely. But I tried to stay active, taking walks, doing light yoga, staying very hydrated and eating well, and all that helped. That was 2008. Had I not done chemo, I know I'd be looking back now thinking...should I have...? At least now I don't have that worry. I mean anyone who has had cancer has enough to worry about for the rest of his or her life, really--but at least I'm not worrying "should I have done chemo...."
Posts.Title: Oncotype DX test score at 18 - chemo or not? julie775 Bamagirl2016

Posts.Content: Nov 28, 2007 08:35PM sharonlouise wrote: thank you thank you everyone so much. I finally slept for a few hours, had a cup of cofee, pet my cats and felt better (if only slightly). I also took your advice & got a scrip for Ativan. I spoke to one of the faculty members here (I'm a grad student & teacher at University of Florida) who nursed her best friend through cancer five years ago, and her friend is fine. She was able to talk me down a bit. Also, speaking to my surgeon did alleviate some anxiety. So am hanging in; I'm really hoping that night was the worst of it. I'm getting a mastectomy. Sometimes I'm ok with it. Sometimes i can't believe it still. My breasts are just about the only area of my body I haven't had an issue with. But anyway. Life goes on. Thank you all so, so much. ---SharonÂ
